entries.title: Wisdom Teeth

entries.title: Let Go
entries.description: After years of trying various methods, I broke this habit by pitting my impatience against my laziness. I decoupled the action and the neurological reward by setting up a simple 30-second delay I had to wait through, in which I couldn't do anything else, before any new page or chat client would load (and only allowed one to run at once). The urge to check all those sites magically vanished--and my 'productive' computer use was unaffected.

entries.title: Major in the Universe

entries.title: Flying Cars

entries.title: Nanobots
entries.description: I think the IETF hit the right balance with the 128 bits thing. We can fit MAC addresses in a /64 subnet, and the nanobots will only be able to devour half the planet.

entries.title: Herpetology
entries.description: Birds are Aves, which is part of the clade Theropoda, which is in Saurischia, which is in Dinosauria. Those birds outside our windows are dinosaurs. We can clear out the rest of our brains because we now have the best fact.

We must join with the darkness. Ba'al the Annihilator offers us no happiness, no answers, naught but the cold embrace of the void. To imagine any other end is delusion. We must give in to the will of Ba'al, for he will one day consume us and our world alike. I therefore call on Congress to fully fund space exploration, and to join with Ba'al, the Eater of Souls. entries.title: Goldbach Conjectures
entries.description: The weak twin primes conjecture states that there are infinitely many pairs of primes. The strong twin primes conjecture states that every prime p has a twin prime (p+2), although (p+2) may not look prime at first. The tautological prime conjecture states that the tautological prime conjecture is true.

Some future reader, who may see the term, without knowing the history of it, may imagine that it had reference to some antiquated bridge of the immortal Poet, thrown across the silver Avon, to facilitate his escape after some marauding excursion in a neighbouring park; and in some Gentleman's Magazine of the next century, it is not impossible, but that future antiquaries may occupy page after page in discussing so interesting a matter. We think it right, therefore, to put it on record in the Oriental Herald that the 'Shakesperian Rope Bridges' are of much less classic origin; that Mr Colin Shakespear, who, besides his dignity as Postmaster, now signs himself 'Superintendent General of Shakesperian Rope Bridges', is a person of much less genius than the Bard of Avon. --The Oriental Herald, 1825

entries.title: Rolle's Theorem
entries.description: I mean, if it's that easy to get a theorem named for you ... "a straight line that passes through the center of a coplanar circle always divides the circle into two equal halves." Can I have that one? Wait, can I auction off the naming rights? It can be the Red Bull Theorem or the Quicken Loans Theorem, depending who wants it more.

entries.title: Boathouses and Houseboats
entries.description: The <x> that is held by <y> is also a <y><x>, so if you go to a food truck, the stuff you buy is truck food. A phone that's in your car is a carphone, and a car equipped with a phone is a phonecar. When you play a mobile racing game, you're in your phonecar using your carphone to drive a different phonecar. I'm still not sure about bananaphones.

entries.description: All I want is a secure system where it's easy to do anything I want. Is that so much to ask?

entries.description: "Is the pipeline literally running from your laptop?" "Don't be silly, my laptop disconnects far too often to host a service we rely on. It's running on my phone."

entries.title: Bluetooth
entries.description: Bluetooth is actually named for the tenth-century Viking king Harald "Bluetooth" Gormsson, but the protocol developed by Harald was a wireless charging standard unrelated to the modern Bluetooth except by name.

entries.title: Horror Movies
entries.description: "Isn't the original Jurassic Park your favorite movie of all time?" "Yes, but that's because I like dinosaurs and I WANT there to be an island full of them. If John Hammond's lab had been breeding serial killers in creepy masks, I wouldn't have watched!" "Wait, are you sure? That could actually be good." "Ok, I WOULD watch the scenes where Jeff Goldblum tries to convince a bunch of executives that the park is a bad idea."

entries.title: Update Your Address
entries.description: This is my four-digit PIN. It was passed down to me by my father, and someday I will pass it on to you. Unless we figure out how to update it, but that sounds complicated.

entries.title: Horror Movies 2
entries.description: When I was a kid, someone told me the end of The Giver was ambiguous, which surprised me. I had just assumed Jonah died--because the book had a medal on the cover, and I knew grown-ups liked stories where sad stuff happens at the end for no reason.

entries.title: Heist
entries.description: But he has a hat AND a toolbox! Where could someone planning a heist get THOSE?

entries.title: Popper
entries.description: At least, I don't think there's evidence. My claim that there's no evidence hasn't been falsified. At least, not that I know of.

entries.title: Alpha Centauri
entries.description: And let's be honest, it's more like two and a half stars. Proxima is barely a star and barely bound to the system.

entries.title: Cohort and Age Effects
entries.description: Younger people get very few joint replacements, yet they're also getting more than older people did at the same age. This means you can choose between 'Why are millennials getting so (many/few) joint replacements?' depending on which trend fits your current argument better.

entries.title: Middle Latitudes
entries.description: Snowy blizzards are fun, but so are warm sunny beaches, so we split the difference by having lots of icy wet slush!

entries.title: Mercator Projection
entries.description: The other great lakes are just water on the far side of Canada Island. If you drive north from the Pacific northwest you actually cross directly into Alaska, although a few officials--confused by the Mercator distortion--have put up border signs.

entries.title: Laptop Issues
entries.description: Hang on, we got a call from the feds. They say we can do whatever with him, but the EPA doesn't want that laptop in the ocean. They're sending a team.

entries.title: FDR
entries.description: June 21st, 365, the date of the big Mediterranean earthquake and tsunami, lived in infamy for a few centuries before fading. Maybe the trick is a catchy rhyme; the '5th of November' thing is still going strong over 400 years later.

entries.title: arXiv
entries.description: Both arXiv and archive.org are invaluable projects which, if they didn't exist, we would dismiss as obviously ridiculous and unworkable.

entries.title: History Department
entries.description: When we take into account the recent discovery of previously-unstudied history in the 1750s, this year may have been an outright loss.

entries.title: Rocket Launch
entries.description: NASA tries to coordinate launch timing with the Care Bears' cloud castle, but unfortunately sometimes collisions with stray Care Bears are unavoidable, so they just try to make the fairings sturdy and hope for a glancing impact.

entries.title: Schwarzschild's Cat
entries.description: Cats can be smaller than the critical limit, but they're unobservable. If one shrinks enough that it crosses the limit, it just appears to get cuter and cuter as it slowly fades from view.

entries.title: Christmas Eve Eve
entries.description: It turns out that saying "Oh, so THAT'S why they call it Boxing Day" is a good way to get punched a second time.

entries.title: Feathered Dinosaur Venn Diagram
entries.description: My pet theory is that in real life, the kid at the beginning of Jurassic Park who made fun of the 'six-foot turkey' never got a talking-to from Dr. Grant, and grew up to produce several of the movie's sequels.

entries.title: Million, Billion, Trillion
entries.description: You can tell most people dont really assign an absolute meaning to these numbers because in some places and time periods, billion has meant 1,000x what it's meant in others, and a lot of us never even noticed.

entries.title: Consensus New Year
entries.description: The biggest jump is at 11:00am EST (4:00pm UTC) when midnight reaches the UTC+8 time zone. That time zone, which includes China, is home to a quarter of the world's population. India and Sri Lanka (UTC+5:30) put us over the 50% mark soon after.

entries.title: Reminders
entries.description: The good news is that if the number of work and friend relationships you have exceeds your willingness to do the bare minimum to keep up with everyone's life events and stuff, one way or another that problem eventually solves itself.

entries.title: Short Selling
entries.description: "I'm selling all my analogies at auction tomorrow, and that witch over there will give you 20 beans if you promise on pain of death to win them for her." "What if SEVERAL people promised witches they'd win, creating some kind of a ... squeeze? Gosh, you could make a lot of" "Don't be silly! That probably never happens."

entries.title: Marsiforming
entries.description: It has so many advantages--it preserves Martian life, requires fewer interplanetary launches, and makes it much easier to field-test Mars rovers.

entries.title: Mattresses
entries.description: After reading that "The War To Sell You A Mattress Is An Internet Nightmare" article, I've decided it's safer and less complicated to just sleep on the floor. DISCLOSURE: THE AUTHOR OF THIS MOUSEOVER TEXT RECEIVED FINANCIAL COMPENSATION FROM THE FLOOR INDUSTRY FOR THIS MESSAGE.

entries.title: Thor Tools
entries.description: CORRECTION: After careful evaluation, we have determined that the axis label on this chart was printed backward.

entries.title: Magnetic Pole
entries.description: People keep trying to come up with reasons that we should worry about the magnetic field collapsing or reversing, but honestly I think it's fine. Whatever minor problems it causes will be made up for by the mid-latitude auroras.

entries.title: Missal of Silos
entries.description: Welcome to Wyoming, motto "We'd like to clarify that Cheyenne Mountain is in Colorado."

entries.title: Models of the Atom
entries.description: J.J. Thompson won a Nobel Prize for his work in electricity in gases, but was unfairly passed over for his "An atom is plum pudding, and plum pudding is MADE of atoms! Duuuuude." theory.

entries.title: Technical Analysis
entries.description: "I [suspect] that we are throwing more and more of our resources, including the cream of our youth, into financial activities remote from the production of goods and services, into activities that generate high private rewards disproportionate to their social productivity. I suspect that the immense power of the computer is being harnessed to this 'paper economy', not to do the same transactions more economically but to balloon the quantity and variety of financial exchanges." --James Tobin, July 1984

entries.title: Internet Archive
entries.description: The fact that things like the npm left-pad incident are so rare is oddly reassuring.

entries.title: Midcontinent Rift System
entries.description: The best wedge issue is an actual wedge.

entries.title: Biff Tannen
entries.description: I can't help myself; now I want to read a bunch of thinkpieces from newspapers in Biff's 1985 arguing over whether the growth of the region into a corporate dystopia was inevitable.

entries.title: Modern OSI Model
entries.description: In retrospect, I shouldn't have used each layer of the OSI model as one of my horcruxes.

entries.title: Sharing Options
entries.description: How about posts that are public, but every time a company accesses a bunch of them, the API makes their CEO's account click 'like' on one of them at random so you get a notification.

entries.title: Launch Risk
entries.description: Don't worry--you're less likely to die from a space launch than from a shark attack. The survival rate is pretty high for both!

entries.title: Carbonated Beverage Language Map
entries.description: There's one person in Missouri who says "carbo bev" who the entire rest of the country HATES.

entries.title: Invisible Formatting
entries.description: To avoid errors like this, we render all text and pipe it through OCR before processing, fixing a handful of irregular bugs by burying them beneath a smooth, uniform layer of bugs.

entries.title: Opportunity Rover
entries.description: Thanks for bringing us along.

entries.title: Night Shift
entries.description: Help, I set my white balance wrong and suddenly everyone is screaming at each other about whether they've been to Colorado.

entries.title: Physics Suppression
entries.description: If physics had a mafia, I'm pretty sure the BICEP2 mess would have ended in bloodshed.

entries.title: Launch Conditions
entries.description: Though I do think the tiny vent on one of the boosters labeled "O-RING" is in poor taste.

entries.title: Plutonium
entries.description: It's like someone briefly joined the team running the universe, introduced their idea for a cool mechanic, then left, and now everyone is stuck pretending that this wildly unbalanced dynamic makes sense.

entries.title: .NORM Normal File Format
entries.description: At some point, compression becomes an  aesthetic design choice. Luckily, SVG is a really flexible format, so there's no reason it can't support vector JPEG artifacts.

entries.title: Differentiation and Integration
entries.description: "Symbolic integration" is when you theatrically go through the motions of finding integrals, but the actual result you get doesn't matter because it's purely symbolic.

entries.title: Normal Distribution
entries.description: It's the NORMAL distribution, not the TANGENT distribution.

entries.title: Video Orientation
entries.description: CIRCULAR VIDEO - PROS: Solves aspect ratio problem. CONS: Never trust anyone who talks to you from inside a circle.

entries.title: Brain Hemispheres
entries.description: Neurologically speaking, the LEFT hand is actually the one at the end of the RIGHT arm.

entries.title: Light Pollution
entries.description: It's so sad how almost no one alive today can remember seeing the galactic rainbow, the insanity nebula, or the skull and glowing eyes of the Destroyer of Sagittarius.

entries.title: Size Venn Diagram
entries.description: Terms I'm going to start using: The Large Dipper, great potatoes, the Big Hadron Collider, and Large Orphan Annie.

entries.title: Meta Collecting
entries.description: I'm trying to get the page locked because some jerk keeps adding "Yachts".

entries.title: Space Mission Hearing
entries.description: Our grant application contains one of those little greeting card speakers that plays spaceship noises when you open it.

entries.title: Luna 2
entries.description: The flags were probably vaporized on impact, because we launched it before we had finished figuring out how to land. That makes sense from an engineering standpoint, but also feels like a metaphor.

entries.title: Google Trends Maps
entries.description: It's early 2020. The entire country is gripped with Marco Rubio fever except for Alaska, which is freaking out. You're frantically studying up on etiquette and/or sexting.

entries.title: Panama Canal
entries.description: Once they selected the other proposal, we could have kept shopping ours around, but we would had to modify it include an aqueduct over their canal, which would be totally unreasonable.

entries.title: New Robot
entries.description: "Some worry that we'll soon have a surplus of search and rescue robots, compared to the number of actual people in situations requiring search and rescue. That's where our other robot project comes in..."

entries.title: 1921 Fact Checker
entries.description: POLITIFACT SAYS: MOSTLY WHATEVER

entries.title: Industry Nicknames
entries.description: As far as "being in the pocket of Big Egg" goes, I think the real threat is Chansey.

entries.title: Emojidome
entries.description: Thank you to the xkcd April 1st volunteers/commentators, including @Chromakode, Kevin, @Aiiane, Patrick, Kat, Reuven, @cotrone, @bstaffin, @zigdon, schwal, Stereo, and everyone who voted!

entries.title: Percentage Styles
entries.description: In a tribute to classical Latin, I started pronouncing it 'per-kent.' Eventually my friends had to resort to spritzing me with a water bottle like a cat to train me out of it.

entries.title: EHT Black Hole Picture
entries.description: [five years later] Ok, it seems we were accidentally zoomed in slightly too far. But imagine there's a cool-looking twisted accretion disc just outside this black square!

entries.title: Too Much Talking
entries.description: Next time I go, I'm going to prepare a whole bunch of opinions that I'm sure are good, and make everyone sit quietly while I run through them.

entries.title: M87 Black Hole Size Comparison
entries.description: I think Voyager 1 would be just past the event horizon, but slightly less than halfway to the bright ring.

entries.title: Election Commentary
entries.description: This really validates Jones's strategy of getting several thousand more votes than Smith. In retrospect, that was a smart move; those votes were crucial.

entries.title: Text Entry
entries.description: I like to think that somewhere out there, there's someone whose personal quest is lobbying TV providers to add an option to switch their on-screen keyboards to Dvorak.

entries.title: Wanna See the Code?
entries.description: And because if you just leave it there, it's going to start contaminating things downstream even if no one touches it directly.

entries.title: Email Settings
entries.description: What are all these less-than signs? What's an HREF? Look, we know you live in a fancy futuristic tech world, but not all of us have upgraded to the latest from Sun Microsystems.

entries.title: Reinvent the Wheel
entries.description: Right now it's a bicycle wheel, so we've had to move to lighter vehicles, but the reduced overhead is worth it. There was one week when a wheel of cheese got dangerously close to the first page, though.

entries.title: UI vs UX
entries.description: U[unprintable glyph]: The elements a higher power uses to bend that moral arc. U[even more unprintable glyph]: The higher power's overall experience bending that moral arc.

entries.title: Dangerous Fields
entries.description: Eventually, every epidemiologist becomes another statistic, a dedication to record-keeping which their colleagues sincerely appreciate.

entries.title: Disk Usage
entries.description: Menu -> Manage -> [Optimize space usage, Encrypt disk usage report, Convert photos to text-only, Delete temporary files, Delete permanent files, Delete all files currently in use, Optimize menu options, Download cloud, Optimize cloud , Upload unused space to cloud]

entries.title: Adjusting a Chair
entries.description: When I was looking at the box, I should have thought more about what "360 degrees of freedom" meant.

entries.title: Heists And Escapes
entries.description: The interactive experience is built on a single theological framework that unites Dante, George R. R. Martin, every major heist movie, and Erin Gloria Ryan's "Kevin is dead" Home Alone theory.

entries.title: Waiting for the But
entries.description: Listen, I'm not a fan of the Spanish Inquisition OR predatory multi-level marketing schemes...

entries.title: Appendicitis
entries.description: Fortunately, after a brief skirmish, I seem to have gained the upper hand in the battle against my internal organs, at least until they learn to read and find out the mean stuff I've said about them.

entries.title: Cubesat Launch
entries.description: Luckily, the damages were partly offset by the prize money we got from accidentally winning the nearby water skiing championship tournament.

entries.title: Alternate Histories
entries.description: "So their universe wouldn't have the iconic photo of a screaming Truman being hoisted aloft by the newspaper-printing machinery..."

entries.title: XKeyboarCD
entries.description: The key caps use LCD displays for all the vowels, so they can automatically adjust over the years to reflect ongoing vowel shifts while allowing you to keep typing phonetically.

entries.title: A/B
entries.description: We wrote our site in Linear A rather than Aksara Kawi because browser testing showed that Crete script rendered faster than Java script.

entries.title: Westerns
entries.description: Sitting here idly trying to figure out how the population of the Old West in the late 1800s compares to the number of Red Dead Redemption 2 players.

entries.title: Effects of High Altitude
entries.description: If she'd lived in Flagstaff (elevation 6,903 feet), Cruella de Vil would only have needed 89 dalmatians for her coat.

entries.title: Motivation
entries.description: What's even worse is, a month ago they transferred me to work on the game I was already playing, and suddenly I found myself procrastinating by playing the one I'd been assigned before. It's possible they're onto me and this is all part of the plan.

entries.title: Swimming
entries.description: "You don't know how high above you the sky goes, but you're not freaking out about that." "Well, NOW I am!"

entries.title: Ufo
entries.description: "It's a little low for a weather balloon; it might be some other kind." "Yeah. Besides, I know I'm the alien conspiracy guy, but come on--the idea that the government would care about hiding something so mundane as atmospheric temperature measurement is too ridiculous even for me."

entries.title: Diploma Legal Notes
entries.description: If you're planning to challenge the royal family, you should probably wait 6-8 weeks, since a number of the younger ones have diplomas and Kate was actually on the varsity lightsaber team at St Andrews.

entries.title: Qualifiers
entries.description: [20 minutes later] ", hi."

entries.title: Comments
entries.description: NPR encourages you to add comments to their stories using the page inspector in your browser's developer tools. Note: Your comments are visible only to you, and will be lost when you refresh the page.

entries.title: Ken Burns Theory
entries.description: Some of the KBCU ancillary works try a little too hard to tie everything together. Doris Kearns Goodwin, the sports journalist featured in "Baseball," was somehow ALSO a famous historian who wrote bestselling biographies of Lincoln AND Johnson? Unrealistic.

entries.title: An Apple a Day
entries.description: Even the powerful, tart Granny Smith cultivar is proving ineffective against new Gran-negative doctors.

entries.title: Literary Opinions
entries.description: If I really focus, I can distinguish between John Steinbeck and John Updike, or between Gore Vidal and Vidal Sassoon, but not both at once.

entries.title: Chernobyl
entries.description: You know when you can't hear your speakers, and you keep turning various volume controls up higher and higher in confusion, and then someone hits the mute button and there's a deafening blast of sound? That's basically what happened at Chernobyl.

entries.title: Glacier
entries.description: The Norwegian adaptation of The Sword in the Stone takes things in a weird direction.

entries.title: Millennials
entries.description: Ironically, I've been having these same arguments for at least a decade now. I thought we would have moved on by now, but somehow the snide complaints about millennials continue.

entries.title: Stack
entries.description: Gotta feel kind of bad for nation-state hackers who spend years implanting and cultivating some hardware exploit, only to discover the entire target database is already exposed to anyone with a web browser.

entries.title: Motivated Reasoning Olympics
entries.description: [later] I can't believe how bad corruption has become, especially given that our league split off from the statewide one a month ago SPECIFICALLY to protest this kind of flagrantly biased judging.

entries.title: Reading in the Original
entries.description: The articles are much shorter, but I assume that's because this version predates the merger with the Hawaiian text that created the modern Hawaiian-Greek hybrid wiki-pedia.

entries.title: Predictive Models
entries.description: WE WILL ARREST THE REVOLUTION MEMBERS [AT THE JULY 28TH MEETING][tab] "Cancel the meeting! Our cover is blown."

entries.title: Coordinate Precision
entries.description: 40 digits: You are optimistic about our understanding of the nature of distance itself.

entries.title: Shadow Biosphere
entries.description: The typical Shadow Biology Department is housed in a building coated in a thin layer of desert varnish which renders it invisible to normal-world university staff.

entries.title: Lunar Cycles
entries.description: The Antikythera mechanism had a whole set of gears specifically to track the cyclic popularity of skinny jeans and low-rise waists.

entries.title: Trained a Neural Net
entries.description: It also works for anything you teach someone else to do. "Oh yeah, I trained a pair of neural nets, Emily and Kevin, to respond to support tickets."

entries.title: First News Memory
entries.description: Psychology researchers say our 'flashbulb' memories of big events can be unreliable, but I clearly remember watching live on CNN as Challenger crashed into and destroyed the Berlin Wall.

entries.title: Flag Interpretation
entries.description: When Salvador Dal died, it took months to get all the flagpoles sufficiently melted.

entries.title: How Hacking Works
entries.description: If only somebody had warned them that the world would roll them like this.

entries.title: Gastroenterology
entries.description: "Mostly it means that I'm acutely aware that the kid one table over coughed as the server walked past with our food."

entries.title: Expiration Date High Score
entries.description: "Wait, we've MOVED since 2010. How on Earth did--" "Look, some of us were just born to be champions."

entries.title: NWS Warnings
entries.description: Kind of rude of them to simultaneously issue an EVACUATION - IMMEDIATE alert, a SHELTER IN PLACE alert, and a 911 TELEPHONE OUTAGE alert.

entries.title: Spreadsheets
entries.description: My brother once asked me if there was a function to produce a calendar grid from a list of dates in Google Sheets. I replied with a single-cell formula that took in a list of dates and outputted a calendar. It used SEQUENCE(), REGEXMATCH(), and a double-nested ARRAYFORMULA(), and it locked up the browser for 15 seconds every time it ran. I think he learned a lot about asking me things.

entries.title: Inbox
entries.description: Rome's declaration of war against Carthage was sent from a no-reply address, so Hannibal had to cross the Alps to deliver his "UNSUBSCRIBE" response in person.

entries.title: When I'm Back at a Keyboard
entries.description: [after typing 1,500 words on feathered dinosaurs, paleontology, sexism, lava, and dinosaurs as animals rather than movie monsters] Sorry to cut it short, I'm on my phone. When I'm back at a keyboard, I can give you another 5,000 words.

entries.title: Icon Swap
entries.description: Someone's probably working on an eBook app where, if you stop reading right before some plot twist happens, the app will wait a while and then send you a breaking news alert about what's happening, prompting you to open it and read the next few pages to learn more.

entries.title: Unpopular Opinions
entries.description: I wasn't a big fan of 3 or Salvation, so I'm trying to resist getting my hopes up too much for Dark Fate, but it's hard. I'm just a sucker for humans and robots traveling through time to try to drive trucks into each other, apparently.

entries.title: Cumulonimbus
entries.description: The rarest of all clouds is the altocumulenticulostratonimbulocirruslenticulomammanoctilucent cloud, caused by an interaction between warm moist air, cool dry air, cold slippery air, cursed air, and a cloud of nanobots.

entries.title: Dark Matter
entries.description: To detect dark matter, we just need to build a bird feeder that spins two squirrels around the rim in opposite directions at relativistic speeds and collides them together.

entries.title: Geologic Time
entries.description: Ok, well, we'll be sure to pay you sometime soon, geologically speaking.

entries.title: E Scooters
entries.description: Obviously battery technology and prices have driven a lot of the scooter explosion, but I feel like Dean Kamen must be at least a little grumpy about how much people laughed at the idea of the Segway.

entries.title: Old Game Worlds
entries.description: Ok, how many coins for a cinnamon roll?

entries.title: Serena Versus the Drones
entries.description: After the test, she said that if she had a choice, she wouldnt defend herself against drones using a tennis ball and racket, though she would absolutely pick them over other sports equipment. But, she added, "Drones don't bother me."

entries.title: Conference Question
entries.description: I also have an utterance. Less of an utterance and more of an incantation. Less of an incantation and more of a malediction. Less of a malediction and more of a Word of Power. Less of a Word of Power and more of an Unforgivable Curse.

entries.title: Review
entries.description: Controls are a little hard to figure out.

entries.title: Well-Ordering Principle
entries.description: We could organize a nationwide old-photo-album search, but the real Worst McFly is probably lost to time.

entries.title: How to Send a File
entries.description: Note: How To will teach you lots of cool stuff about technology, data storage, butterfly migration, and more. Also you will never see your files again.

entries.title: Dockless Roombas
entries.description: The company started out exploiting a loophole in the law banning scooters. The city was mad at first, but then they noticed how much they were saving on street cleaning.

entries.title: Nice To E-Meet You
entries.description: I'm inside your head and I hate it. Please let me out.

entries.title: Game Show
entries.description: Eventually they agreed to "an auto-retracting dog leash with one end clipped to your house, so you can press the button on the handle and water-ski home."

entries.title: Cryptic Wifi Networks
entries.description: They actually showed up on the first scan by the first WiFi-capable device.

entries.title: Unreachable State
entries.description: ERROR: We've reached an unreachable state. Anything is possible. The limits were in our heads all along. Follow your dreams.

entries.title: Foucault Pendulum
entries.description: Trust me, you don't want to get on the wrong side of the paramilitary enforcement arm of the International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service.

entries.title: Earth-Like Exoplanet
entries.description: Fire is actually a potential biosignature, since it means something is filling the atmosphere with an unstable gas like oxygen. If we find a planet covered in flames, it might be an indicator that it supports life. Or used to, anyway, before the fire.

entries.title: Prescience
entries.description: Lots of people called their ships unsinkable before the Titanic. Voicing your hubris doesn't make failure more likely, just more memorable.

entries.title: Ksp 2
entries.description: "The committee appreciates that your 2020 launch is on track, but the 'human capital/personnel retention' budget includes a lot more unmarked cash payments than usual. What are th--" "Public outreach."

entries.title: Types of Approximation
entries.description: It's not my fault I haven't had a chance to measure the curvature of this particular universe.

entries.title: Mavis Beacon
entries.description: There are actually lowercase-like 'oldstyle' forms of normal numbers with more pronounced ascenders and descenders, which is why some numbers like '5' in books sometimes dangle below the line. But the true capital numbers remain the domain of number maven Mavis Beacon.

entries.title: Math Work
entries.description: I could type this into a solver, which MIGHT help, but would also mean I have to get a lot of parentheses right...

entries.title: Drone Fishing
entries.description: Today's consumers who order their drones off the internet don't know the joy of going out in nature and returning with a drone that you caught yourself, whose angry owners you fought off with your own two hands.

entries.title: Fresh Pears
entries.description: I want to sell apples but I'm still working on getting the machine to do the cutting and grafting.

entries.title: College Athletes
entries.description: Their signature play is the three-point combinator, a recursive offense which is guaranteed not to halt and continues accumulating points until the buzzer.

entries.title: Hours Before Departure
entries.description: They could afford to cut it close because they all had Global Entry.

entries.title: Cell Phone Functions
entries.description: ... tazer ... fire extinguisher ... bird feeder ... toilet paper ...

entries.title: How Old
entries.description: We've met! I remember you when you were thiiiis tall! [*holds a hand an inch above their head*]

entries.title: Chemistry Nobel
entries.description: Most chemists thought the lanthanides and actinides could be inserted in the sixth and seventh rows, but no, they're just floating down at the bottom with lots more undiscovered elements all around them.

entries.title: Faculty:Student Ratio
entries.description: They managed to briefly hit the top of the rankings when they rejected everyone except one applicant, published 5 billion research papers that just said "Hi," and hired one of their graduates for $50 trillion/year (then fired them after 10 microseconds.)

entries.title: Percent Milkfat
entries.description: "So what's dark energy?" "Cosmologists and the FDA are both trying very hard to find out."

entries.title: 53 Cards
entries.description: Well, there's one right here at the bottom, where it says "53."

entries.title: Wardrobe
entries.description: If you'd just agree to hold your meetings in here, you'd have PLENTY of time to figure things out before the deadline.

entries.title: Earthquake Early Warnings
entries.description: I was fired by the National Weather Service five minutes after they hired me for going into their code base and renaming all the tornado warnings to "tornado spoiler alerts."

entries.title: Imagine Going Back in Time
entries.description: I wonder what the trendy adults in 2019 who are too cool for Pokemon will be into. Probably Digimon!

entries.title: Emulation
entries.description: I laugh at the software as if I'm 100% confident that it's 2019.

entries.title: Terminator: Dark Fate
entries.description: I was sent here to stop the robot that was sent here to protect the human who was sent here to protect the human who was sent here to destroy the robot that was sent here to vacuum the floor.

entries.title: Screen Time
entries.description: These new Bluetooth socks are great, but it's troubling to learn that I average almost 14 hours of Shoe Time a day.

entries.title: Software Updates
entries.description: Everything is a cloud application; the ping times just vary a lot.

entries.title: Voting Referendum
entries.description: The weirdest quirk of the Borda count is that Jean-Charles de Borda automatically gets one point; luckily this has no consequences except in cases of extremely low turnout.

entries.title: Recombination And Reionization
entries.description: These signals seem to be pre-star-formation but post-Malone.

entries.title: Transit of Mercury
entries.description: For some reason the water in my pool is green and there's a weird film on the surface #nofilter

entries.title: Machine Learning Captcha
entries.description: More likely: Click on all the pictures of people who appear disloyal to [name of company or government]

entries.title: Rey and Kylo
entries.description: We're like 10+ movies in and the focus has been almost entirely on the WARS half.

entries.title: Versus Bracket
entries.description: Some works didn't make the cut; in "Ecks vs. Sever" vs. the passage of time, the latter seems to have won pretty decisively.

entries.title: The Time Before and After Land
entries.description: According to Google, "the time for Beeland" is apparently whenever you're looking for delicious honey in Spillimacheen, British Columbia or a hexagonal chalet in the Savinja valley in Slovenia.

entries.title: Hotel Room Party
entries.description: [proudly greeting the hotel manager at the door] "Did I do a good job?"

entries.title: Aurora Meaning
entries.description: The astro-ph.SR arXiv servers are simultaneously being overwhelmed by electronic requests and actual electricity.

entries.title: How To Deliver Christmas Presents
entries.description: Building codes in hurricane zones rely on studies of how easily flying debris can break residential windows. If you're looking for a science fair project idea and you hate your neighbors, I'm sure they could always use more data!

entries.title: Group Chat Rules
entries.description: There's no group chat member more enigmatic than the cool person who you all assume has the chat on mute, but who then instantly chimes in with no delay the moment something relevant to them is mentioned.

entries.title: Is it Christmas?
entries.description: We've tested it on 30 different days and it hasn't gotten one wrong yet.

entries.title: AI Hiring Algorithm
entries.description: So glad Kate over in R&D pushed for using the AlgoMaxAnalyzer to look into this. Hiring her was a great decisio- waaaait.

entries.title: Flu Shot
entries.description: "Wait, how often are you getting bitten by snakes? And why are you boiling water?" "Dunno, the CDC people keep showing up with complicated questions about the 'history of the property' and 'possible curses' but I kinda tune them out. At least one of them offered me the flu shot."
